dict.string: Screensaver payloads are designated by specifying com.apple.screensaver as the PayloadType. The device level screensaver payload can be used to customize the screensaver and enable or disable the screen lock password function.
The human-readable description of this payload. This description appears on the Detail screen.
The human-readable name for the profile payload. The name appears on the Detail screen and doesn't need to be unique.

The reverse-DNS-style identifier for the payload. This identifier is usually the same as the TopLevel value, with an additional appended component. This string must be unique within the profile. During a profile replacement, the system updates payloads with the same 'PayloadIdentifier' and 'PayloadUUID' in the old and new profiles.
The payload type, which each payload domain's reference page specifies.

The globally unique identifier for the payload. The actual content is unimportant, but must be globally unique. In macOS, use 'uuidgen' to generate UUIDs. During a profile replacement, the system updates payloads with the same 'PayloadIdentifier' and 'PayloadUUID' in the old and new profiles.
The version of this specific payload.

The version number of the individual payload. A profile can consist of payloads with different version numbers. For example, changes to the VPN software in iOS might introduce a new payload version to support additional features, but Mail payload versions would not necessarily change in the same release.
The human-readable string containing the name of the organization that provides the profile. This value doesn't need to match the organization payload value in the enclosing dictionary.

Optional. A human-readable string containing the name of the organization that provided the profile. The payload organization for a payload need not match the payload organization in the enclosing profile.
If 'true', the user is prompted for a password when the screen saver is unlocked or stopped. When you use this prompt, you must also provide 'askForPasswordDelay'. Available in macOS 10.13 and later.

Optional. If true, the user will be prompted for a password when the screensaver is unlocked or stopped. When using this prompt, askForPasswordDelay must also be provided. Availability: Available in macOS 10.13 and later.

The number of seconds to delay before the password will be required to unlock or stop the screen saver (the grace period). A value of '2147483647' (for example, '0x7FFFFFFF') disables this requirement. To use this option, you must set 'askForPassword' to 'true'. Available in macOS 10.13 and later.

Optional. Number of seconds to delay before the password will be required to unlock or stop the screen saver (the ”grace period”). A value of 2147483647 (eg 0x7FFFFFFF) can be used to disable this requirement, and on 10.13, the payload is one of the only ways of disabling the feature. Note that askForPassword must be set to true to use this option. Availability: Available in macOS 10.13 and later.
The full path to the screen-saver module to use.
The number of seconds of inactivity before the screen saver activates (0 = Never activate).
Optional. Number of seconds of inactivity before screensaver activates. (0=never activate). Availability: Available in macOS 10.11 and later.
Number of seconds of inactivity before screensaver activates. (0 = never activate).
Optional. Number of seconds of inactivity before screensaver activates. (0=never activate). Availability: Available in macOS 10.11 and later.
The name of the screen saver module.
The property is officially documented as required, however user reports and testing on macOS 14.4.1 have confirmed it to be optional.
